required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Study to Evaluate How VI-0521 Affect Psychomotor Performance in Healthy Overweight and Obese Subjects.
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase 2, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Cross-over Study to Evaluate the Psychomotor Effect of VI-0521 in Healthy Overweight and Obese Subjects.

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine how VI-0521 affect speed and reaction time on specific tasks that require eye and hand coordination, compared to placebo.

primary_outcome.measure: Measure of Psychomotor Function Using Speed and Coordination on the CogScreen Pathfinder Number (PFN) Test in Subjects Treated With Alcohol Compared to Alcohol Placebo in Period 1.
primary_outcome.description: CogScreen-Psychomotor Edition (CogScreen-PM) consists of a series of computerized cognitive tasks, each self-contained and presented with instructions and a practice segment. The test battery takes about 20-25 minutes to perform. Performance on the test will be measured as the median reaction time for correct responses (PFNRTC) and coordination errors (PFNCOOR) before and after treatment. The measures of the tests are: (a) response speed, the median response time to complete each sequential step (PFNRTC); (b) response accuracy (PF Number Accuracy [PFNACC]); and (c) a coordination measure indicating the respondent's proximity to the center of the target numbers and letters (PF Number Coordination [PFNCOOR]). PF measures number sequencing skills, immediate memory, psychomotor speed and coordination, and visual scanning. The normal range for PFN scores is 1.17-2.16. Scores that are higher than this range indicate some level of psychomotor impairment.

primary_outcome.measure: Measure of Psychomotor Function Using Speed and Coordination on the CogScreen Pathfinder Number (PFN) Test in Subjects Treated With VI-0521 Compared to Placebo in Periods 2 and 3.
primary_outcome.description: CogScreen-Psychomotor Edition (CogScreen-PM) consists of a series of computerized cognitive tasks, each self-contained and presented with instructions and a practice segment. The test battery takes about 20-25 minutes to perform. Performance on the test will be measured as the median reaction time for correct responses (PFNRTC) and coordination errors (PFNCOOR) before and after treatment. The measures of the tests are: (a) response speed, the median response time to complete each sequential step (PFNRTC); (b) response accuracy (PF Number Accuracy [PFNACC]); and (c) a coordination measure indicating the respondent's proximity to the center of the target numbers and letters (PF Number Coordination [PFNCOOR]). PF measures number sequencing skills, immediate memory, psychomotor speed and coordination, and visual scanning. The normal range for PFN scores is 1.17-2.16. Scores that are higher than this range indicate some level of psychomotor impairment.

arm_group.description: Dosed first with alcohol, then active VI-0521, and last, VI-0521 placebo
First dosed with alcohol placebo (fruit juice), then active VI-0521, and last, placebo VI-0521
First dosed with alcohol, then VI-0521 placebo, and last, active VI-0521
First dosed with alcohol placebo, then VI-0521 placebo, and last, active VI-0521

intervention.description: Phentermine 3.75 mg and topiramate 23 mg daily for the 1st week; Phentermine 7.5 mg and topiramate 46 mg daily for the 2nd week; Phentermine 11.25 mg and topiramate 69 mg daily for the 3rd week; Phentermine 15 mg and topiramate 92 mg daily for the 4th week

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Subject recruitment occurred within the US between January 2009 and March 2009
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Period 1 was not a crossover design. Subjects were randomized to either alcohol or alcohol-placebo. Subjects who completed Period 1 were then randomized to the crossover portion of the study, Periods 2 and 3.

group.title: Alcohol, VI-0521 Placebo Then VI-0521
group.description: Alcohol was administered during period one followed by one week washout, VI-0521 placebo for four weeks during period two followed by one week washout, then VI-0521 titrated over four weeks during period three.

group.title: Alcohol, VI-0521 Then VI-0521 Placebo
group.description: Alcohol was administered during period one followed by one week washout, VI-0521 titrated over four weeks during period two followed by one week washout, then VI-0521 placebo for four weeks during period three.

group.title: Alcohol-placebo, VI-0521-placebo Then VI-0521
group.description: Alcohol-placebo was administered during period one followed by one week washout, VI-0521 placebo for four weeks during period two followed by one week washout, then VI-0521 titrated over four weeks during period three.

group.title: Alcohol-placebo, VI-0521 Then VI-0521-placebo
group.description: Alcohol-placebo was administered during period one followed by one week washout, VI-0521 titrated over four weeks during period two followed by one week washout, then VI-0521 placebo for four weeks during period three.

group.title: Alcohol Only
group.description: Alcohol was administered during period one after which the subject's participation ended.

group.title: Alcohol-placebo Only
group.description: Alcohol-placebo was administered during period one after which the subject's participation ended.

participants_list.participants: did not move onto Periods 2 and 3 due to adjusted design of study
did not move onto Periods 2 and 3 due to adjusted design of study

group.title: Alcohol, VI-0521 Placebo Then VI-0521
group.description: Participants in this study arm were given alcohol in period 1, VI-0521 placebo in period 2 and VI-0521 in period 3.

group.title: Alcohol, VI-0521 Then VI-0521 Placebo
group.description: Participants in this study arm were given alcohol in period 1, VI-0521 in period 2 and VI-0521-placebo in period 3.

group.title: Alcohol Placebo, VI-0521 Placebo Then VI-0521
group.description: Participants in this study arm were given alcohol placebo in period 1, VI-0521-placebo in period 2 and VI-0521 in period 3.

group.title: Alcohol Placebo, VI-0521 Then VI-0521 Placebo
group.description: Participants in this study arm were given alcohol placebo in period 1, VI-0521 in period 2 and VI-0521 placebo in period 3.

group.title: Alcohol Only
group.description: Subjects in this study arm only participated in period 1 and were given alcohol.

group.title: Alcohol Placebo Only
group.description: Subject in this study arm only participated in period 1 and were given alcohol placebo.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

outcome.title: Measure of Psychomotor Function Using Speed and Coordination on the CogScreen Pathfinder Number (PFN) Test in Subjects Treated With Alcohol Compared to Alcohol Placebo in Period 1.
outcome.description: CogScreen-Psychomotor Edition (CogScreen-PM) consists of a series of computerized cognitive tasks, each self-contained and presented with instructions and a practice segment. The test battery takes about 20-25 minutes to perform. Performance on the test will be measured as the median reaction time for correct responses (PFNRTC) and coordination errors (PFNCOOR) before and after treatment. The measures of the tests are: (a) response speed, the median response time to complete each sequential step (PFNRTC); (b) response accuracy (PF Number Accuracy [PFNACC]); and (c) a coordination measure indicating the respondent’s proximity to the center of the target numbers and letters (PF Number Coordination [PFNCOOR]). PF measures number sequencing skills, immediate memory, psychomotor speed and coordination, and visual scanning. The normal range for PFN scores is 1.17-2.16. Scores that are higher than this range indicate some level of psychomotor impairment.

group.title: Period 1 Alcohol-placebo
group.description: fruit juice

group.title: Period 1 Alcohol
group.description: Alcohol

outcome.title: Measure of Psychomotor Function Using Speed and Coordination on the CogScreen Pathfinder Number (PFN) Test in Subjects Treated With VI-0521 Compared to Placebo in Periods 2 and 3.
outcome.description: CogScreen-Psychomotor Edition (CogScreen-PM) consists of a series of computerized cognitive tasks, each self-contained and presented with instructions and a practice segment. The test battery takes about 20-25 minutes to perform. Performance on the test will be measured as the median reaction time for correct responses (PFNRTC) and coordination errors (PFNCOOR) before and after treatment. The measures of the tests are: (a) response speed, the median response time to complete each sequential step (PFNRTC); (b) response accuracy (PF Number Accuracy [PFNACC]); and (c) a coordination measure indicating the respondent’s proximity to the center of the target numbers and letters (PF Number Coordination [PFNCOOR]). PF measures number sequencing skills, immediate memory, psychomotor speed and coordination, and visual scanning. The normal range for PFN scores is 1.17-2.16. Scores that are higher than this range indicate some level of psychomotor impairment.
outcome.population: Intent-to-treat (ITT) ITT population includes participants who completed Periods 1, 2 and 3. Subjects that were discontinued due to adverse events, failed drug/alcohol screens, non-compliance, etc. are not included in this analysis.

group.title: Period 2 VI-0521-placebo
group.description: Placebo

group.title: Period 2 VI-0521
group.description: phentermine/topiramate

group.title: Period 3 VI-0521-placebo
group.description: placebo

group.title: Period 3 VI-0521
group.description: phentermine/topiramate

measure.title: Measure of Psychomotor Function Using Speed and Coordination on the CogScreen Pathfinder Number (PFN) Test in Subjects Treated With VI-0521 Compared to Placebo in Periods 2 and 3.
measure.description: CogScreen-Psychomotor Edition (CogScreen-PM) consists of a series of computerized cognitive tasks, each self-contained and presented with instructions and a practice segment. The test battery takes about 20-25 minutes to perform. Performance on the test will be measured as the median reaction time for correct responses (PFNRTC) and coordination errors (PFNCOOR) before and after treatment. measure.population: Intent-to-treat (ITT) ITT population includes participants who completed Periods 1, 2 and 3. Subjects that were discontinued due to adverse events, failed drug/alcohol screens, non-compliance, etc. are not included in this analysis.

reported_events.time_frame: AEs were collected from when written informed consent was provided through 28 days after the last dose of investigational product.

group.title: Period 2 and 3 Placebo
group.description: Total number of subjects that were given VI-0521 placebo was 43. 1 subject was excluded from the analysis due to failing a drug/alcohol screen leaving 42 subjects in the ITT population.

group.title: Period 2 and 3 Qnexa
group.description: The total number of subjects that were given VI-0521 was 41. 2 subjects were excluded from the analysis, one due to failing a drug/alcohol screen and the other due to pregnancy. Excluding these two subjects leaves 39 subjects in the analyzed ITT population.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: After Sponsor's written notification that publication of results is no longer planned or 12 months after termination of the study at all sites, Institution & PI may publish, upon written approval from Sponsor, results of the Study. Sponsor will be given the opportunity to review any proposed publication at least 60 days prior to submission for publication or disclosure. Upon Sponsor's written request, Institution and PI shall not publish or disclose information related to the Study.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Due to technical issues, an additional cohort of subjects were added to Period 1 only, which produced two additional treatment arms, alcohol only and alcohol placebo only. No change was made in the data analysis.
